My favorite Japanese Style BBQ!!! Love all the chicken ones!!! You should try the tofu for dessert, it's amazing!!!
Very nice place with very well balanced flavors and textures. Deep fried tofu was amazing, miso soup was one of the best I've ever had, and the tuna was prepared very nicely. A+ on service for sure.

Good service, good food. Loved the skewers and the raw fish. Don't bother getting the normal stuff like agedashi tofu.. It's not worth the money. For the price of the restaurant you want the unique stuff. Long wait, for a seat but they call you so I guess you can walk around for an hour or two.

Great yakitori place. Got the chicken breast with scallion, chicken oyster, steamed chicken rice balls, lamb chop, chicken rice with scallions. The cold udon looked great too but we were stuffed. Cool little spot to hang out and have a asahi. It's located north of the theatre district- great late night dining.
probably one of the only decent restaurants in this immediate area. the food is good but not great. there is a good range of different japanese dishes and the yaki's are the best things on the menu.
Delicious food. Staffs are amazing, wonderful service. Good environment for friends, couples, singles or even families. We went with our daughter 4 years old, and she loved the food.

Tiny place, but the food is awesome! This place features a open kitchen so you can see the Japanese chief working really hard to make sure every skillet is perfect. Love chicken knee bones (don't know if it's still on the menu), the rice ball is awesome too!

One of my favorite places to go yakitori in the city! We ordered probably 40 skewers, beer, and some sides. Try everything and everything will be well done not dry...from hearts, skin, mushrooms, eggplant, and etc. You can't go wrong! You can make rsvp ahead of time or try your luck. We went at 7pm (4 of us) and they told us we could either be seated in 10 mins if we had everyone or on the wait list for an hour. We made the 10 minute cut and had a great dinner.

Still awesome for yakitori.  Be sure to come a bit early like 5 or 6pm to score a table and feast on the "limited menu" of chicken tails, hearts, gizzards, etc which run out fast.  Also great were the grilled onigiri, tofu dessert, shime saba, bacon wrapped enoki mushrooms, etc.

Food is always amazing here despite the slow service and long wait times.  Best to show up early, put your name down, then hang out elsewhere for a while.  They also won't seat you until your entire party is there and the waiting area is very cramped.  Service is always polite and courteous, just a little slow, but it takes time create such lovely food!  Some of my favorite yakitori options there - chicken oyster (they run out quick so put this order in first!), chicken meatball, bacon wrapped enoki, chicken liver, chicken hearts, skirt steak... Those are my must haves, but I've never eaten anything that was not delicious here.  The dessert menu is also very creative - I especially love the green tea affogato.  Happy eating!!
Most legit and delicious yakatori experience I've had so far in the USA. Find yourself here or forever regret your poor life choices.

This place has a $20 minimum for each person, meaning each person has to order at least $20 worth of food, or the average price per person must be $20. For instance, if there are three people, you must order $60 worth of food. This is not a bad thing; it's actually pretty easy to spend $20 per person here. Yakitori is known for their huge variety of skewers. They cook each skewer fresh, right after you order. There is a list of skewers to choose from the chicken list and same with the lamb, beef, and seafood. All skewers had beautiful flavors to them and very enjoyable. My favorite skewer is the chicken meatball, which was exploding with flavor in every bite. Pretty good place!
Excellent service, wonderful food, and an atmosphere that honestly makes me feel cooler than I am.

Exactly what I hoped it would be.  Authentic, tasty, and a great variety.  Even a few Japanese "shop girls" eating alone at the counter, just like in Japan.  Production line operation behind the counter, skewering, then turning and grilling and basting.  Everything was delicious.

Long wait. Felt like we were skipped over for regulars. Despite that. Wife pounded the chicken skin.  I passed. Chicken, meatball, beef, asparagus w bacon, scallion skewers were great. Ate MANY skewers and would go back. Small and be ready to wait, but worth the wait

I went here a few weeks ago, it was a very long wait to get a table since we didn't have a reservation.  Which I was surprised about on a Monday night after 8pm.  I thought the food was very good and tasty, but over priced.  And it was a long wait to get the food.  I might come here again if I was in the mood for yakitori, they do a great job but again the long wait and the price kind of put me off.  I would look around for another yakitori place in the city.
First restaurant I found in Manhattan with soft bone (软骨)! The food was great and service was decent. Will definitely go back for the food.

This place is delicious, but if you go there on a date, don't scream when he receives his chicken hearts on a stick because he won't call you back.

yeah baby. Yakitori to the illlest. I came here for lunch today to celebrate working overtime and the ability to digest properly after settling my nerves from a new job. Had a big bowl of lunch for 10 dollars. That's the stuff.

I went here last night before the Herbie Hancock show at Carnegie Hall. The food was universally amazing. We ate almost everything on the menu, so if there's a clunker on there - then I just didn't encounter it last night. This is a great alternative to the sea of mediocre, theatre district options. A little warning. The place is cute as a button, but it is also  TINY. We were lucky enough to snag a table, but I don't recommend taking your chances. Make a reservation!
(FIRE EMOJI x5) prepare for wait but worth it -- cozy Japanese ambiance skewed slightly towards higher energy

No comment

Came here twice during our 1-week vacation in NYC. Tried different meat, seafood, and veggie skewers and loved everything! The food was grilled so perfectly that it was juicy or tender inside and not burnt outside. Shiitake mushroom, eggplants, bacon wrapped enoki mushroom, and chicken thighs were our favorite. Best Yakitori place in Manhattan hands down.

There's a lot of delicious chicken pieces--I particularly enjoy the oysters (if they're available).  The service is polite, albiet a bit frenetic and hurried.  It's definitely an interesting dinner but if you go on an empty stomach, it can get expensive quite quickly.  The plum wine pairs well with most food options.  Sapporo is always a safe bet as well.

The food was definitely flavorful and delicious, however the playlist was questionable. There was so much 2000s pop -- more appropriate at a bat mitzvah than a hip Japanese restaurant. During our 1 hour dinner, we were serenaded by Kesha's "Sleazy," One Direction's "Rock Me," and the Jonas Brother's smash single "Burnin' Up." Needless to say, the playlist made dinner...memorable. But the food is honestly fantastic, and that's all that really matters.
No comment
And when a cat gives up fish for chicken, you know what that means.

Just sit at the bar and watch the Japanese dudes turn those skewers of chicken junk on the mini grill and you'll know you're in for a good meal. Mind you, the wait can be long (luckily, you can put your name down and they'll call your mobile), but it's worth it. And, yes, the tastier chicken parts do run out if you're there later at night (something to do with limited supply from a local chicken farm - maybe you locavores appreciate this). I'd say you can't really go wrong here unless you're expecting a cheap meal a la the St. Mark's yakitori joints. Out.

We were looking for a place to eat at around 10 or 11 at night and Totto was open. My husband liked it here, but I'm a creature of habit and I'm such a huge fan of Shinsen Gumi in Gardena it was really hard not to compare it to LA's finest yakitori. BUT I dont doubt we'll probably visit Totto again when in NY because my husband enjoyed it. I'm giving it 2 stars and I'll add one for my partner. You enter the door, walk down the stairs and its pretty happening in there so with a group of friends and sake bombs, it's definitely a good happy hour joint. We sat at the bar so the bartenders were friendly and chill. All in all, I would try it again before saying no way to this place.
Nice atmosphere. Efficient service. Decent price for tasty yakatori. I got a rice bowl which was heavy on the rice and low on vegetables but overall the meal was fine.

No comment
No comment

Adventure-loving foodie adults will of course love eating here so this review is really for the parents -- go ahead and take your kids here. Kids love food on sticks and you love food, en stick. Just go early so that you can avoid the long line down the stairs.

I can't really add much more to what others have said.  I'll keep it short and sweet.  If you like grilled stuff and if you're adventurous with trying new things (chicken... knees??) then you must try this place.  The food is so great and the grilled stuff on sticks is ultra fabulous.  It's an experience well worth the wait and the price.

I love that this place is on the second floor, I love that they take no reservations, and I love how small and cozy this place is... Sometimes the service can be extremely slow, which really doesn't help out much with the extremely long lines... I've never had a dish here that blew me away or left me gasping for air, but everything is at least good to very good... Also, nothing is very cheap. You may be unpleasantly surprised when the check arrives at meal's end... I like this place, it's a good spot for bringing friends visiting from out of town... Their soju cocktails are a bit weak compared to other places I've had them (or how I make them at home)... The best thing I've had here is the homemade tofu.
No comment

It wasn't until I came here that I really, truly appreciated how delicious my mother's yakitori is.  I know she lives in Seattle and she doesn't have a restaurant, but if you ever have the chance to eat her food you should go for it with bare hands and a bib.  I love greasy crispy gyoza and they do have this.  I recommend ignoring the menu except for the Chef's Selections, and then have your waiter/waitress pick from that menu what you should eat.  And if you've not tried gizzards and heart and neck and cartilige, well, why not give it a shot?  Because the chicken breast is so bland it'll make you want to spit it into your napkin b.c it's such an absolute waste of stomach space.

One of my go to restaurants in the city. It's one of the BEST yakitori spots in Manhattan. I had been to, I believe, every yakitori restaurants in the city but always end here. There is a bit of a wait during dinner time but it is worth it! Come during business lunch hours if you want to avoid the lines but a MUST try if you like yakitori or never tried it.

First of all, Yelp Management, this is NOT a Dim Sum house. This is a Yakitori-ya or a grilled chicken restaurant. Yakitori Totto is amazing. Be prepared to dine on grilled chicken thighs, gizzards, liver, heart, pork loin, grilled smelt, amazing seaweed salad, grilled rice balls with miso paste, all washed down with a selection of Japanese beers and umeshu (plum wine) mixed with sparkling water. I have been coming to this restaurant for five years (averaging twice a year) and it has always been good. I can't wait to go back!

The restaurant was closing in 20 minutes and with other guests still inside we were asked to leave. I would advise another choice on the street which would allow guests to stay and finish their meal and not interrupt you mid bite to dismiss you.

No comment

Crazy good. I didn't have anything bad. One of the better sticks, surprisingly, was the tomatoes. Chicken thighs were delicious. Bacon wrapped asparagus was fantastic. The asparagus was 'al dente', and the bacon was nice and crispy. Definitely worth a trip and not that bad in terms of price.
No comment

Food is cold when served, terrible attitude from the waitress, especially the head waitress. We did not even get water for a long time. Always felt like they were sneering at us. Gave us a check before we asked for it, seemed to rush us out. All in all, I won't return.

YUMS! Excellent food and super polite service. I can still hear my server's drawn out "thank youuuuu" and his calm, zen presence. My party of three had to wait more than an hour to get seated for dinner, but the time passed quickly as we shopped in the nearby TIme Warner Center. All of the dishes we ordered were top notch, particularly the meat skewers with scallions mmmm. Please leave room for dessert since their desserts are surprisingly amazing as well! FIVE+++ STARS!

Good food overall. I got the eel box and it was quite generous. It wasn't the best sushi I had in the world, but I would say everything is consistently above average compared to sushi restaurants, including the service. It is very popular though and you have to be prepared to wait. It's also a bit pricey.
No comment

Chicken skin yakitori - crunchy on the outside, melts like buttah on the inside!...  The food here is very, very flavorful.  It's best enjoyed with friends, but if you come here solo like I did, don't hesitate to pig out.  It's worth the calories.  The eggplant dish is delicious.  I don't know if I should be doing it, but I slurped the tasty broth like I haven't eaten in three days.  The Amakara Age is also really, really delicious.  Hmm.. I'm salivating now just thinking about this place all over again.

What a wonderful place to try! A variety of crazy food with so much flavor. You MUST TRY the Pork Belly! The staff was very nice and helpful. And other than the rowdy table next to us, a perfect experience. Either that or I'm totally on a food high!
No comment

Overall, a satisfying experience. Prices are a bit high for what you get -- like most yakitori/tapas style places you need to order quite a bit to fill up -- but I've had friendly and prompt service on each of my two visits and have enjoyed most of the dishes I've tried. It's a small place, but it's cute and feels pretty authentic. The food is quite tasty as well. I particularly recommend the tako wasa, agedashi tofu, lamb chop, chicken oyster and kalbi.

A friend took me here.   I had no idea what I was in for - and it was perfect.  The fish cakes are among the best I've ever had.   The terrible thing is that I lost the business card and was totally unable to figure out where I had gone.   Finally I found the card!
Awesome lunch deal, I order the Totto Don it some with miso soup and salad, the yakitori all fresh and hand grill it when you put ur order!!! Highly recommended for lunch!

Wow, chicken knee bones taste like... bones.  I always thought I was an adventurous eater, but it turns out I was wrong.  I'm sure if you like this kind of stuff, Yakitori Totto is great.  But we had to order extra beer to get up to the $20 minimum.  I just didn't want to eat anything else.

I came here for dinner on a Friday night. It was a completely underwhelming experience from start to finish. Dishes on their menu labeled "Veg" contained fish flakes. Anyone with allergies or dietary restrictions beware. The one redeeming dish was the frozen banana dessert. I will not be back.
Good food. Reasonably priced. Located around Times Square where everything feels touristy and crowded, but his place feels local and authentic.

The yakitori here was awesome.  Every bite is heavenly... I can almost recall with perfect clarity the wonderfulness of the beef tongue and it's other tasty food partners.  I would happily frequent this place if I lived in NY.  Beware the wait, it was long, but thankfully the hostess took our cell phone and called us when they were ready.

Food and service was adequate. The yakitori was good, well flavored, not too salty. Nothing was overcooked and it was mostly a pleasant experience. The only complaint I had was one of the waitress forgetting to put in one of my orders, so it seemed like I was waiting for nothing. Other than that, this place was pretty good and most likely will revisit.

I've never had a bad time here on four different visits over several years. It's a fun place, the servers may be a bit gruff but overall are welcoming and attentive, and once you get a seat no one rushes you out. Get the yakitori, it's a yakitori restaurant. Drink beer and sake and grab the fried chicken if your are extra hungry. Make a reservation and go early to get the specialty cuts. This is one of my favorite places in the city!
No comment

When the line for Totto is too long, walk 2 blocks and dine here.  I dropped by for their Paitan beef ramen during lunch and it was ridiculously good.  It's still not up there with Totto, I think atmosphere has a lot to do with it, but the temperature of the broth isn't as hot as it should be.  Their other lunch specials are reasonable as well.  ~$10 gets you a quality house salad w/ sesame ginger dressing, miso soup and a rice bowl with 3 skewers.  The kicker?  Onsen tamago is included!  I wasn't smart enough to ask for it with my ramen last time I was here but you can bet I wont make that mistake again.
No comment

Ah, it's a shame that it's been so long since I've been here. Some quick tips: Go early to beat the dinner theater rush. Sit at the bar. And order the "strangest" looking items on the menu. You know, the chicken skin, the soft cartilage, etc. Unfortunately, I wasn't brave enough to have the chicken sashimi. There are two private rooms in the... front of the restaurant. Interestingly enough, they're enclosed in glass, so you can sometimes look in. Not that I, umm, meant to.
No comment

I'm a yakitori nut, so for me to find a restaurant of this quality so near my place (five streets away from my HK joint) is truly a blessing. For the more adventurous diner, the chicken liver and heart is divine. More traditional foodies will find the chicken thigh, pork with scallions, and enoki bacon hard to resist. To make sure you leave full, grab one of the chicken with egg rice bowls. I've never left Yakitori Totto unsatisfied, and that goes for the people I take there as well. The place is small, so go early and enjoy!

My favorite Yakitori place in town. Everything cooked just right. Good service, tasty dishes including their apptizers and Yakitori. They also keep changing their menu a bit once a while. It is a bit pricy but it is worth it. They only take reservations for party of 4 or more. Highly recommend if you appreciate good food.

No comment

Love this place! Everything from going upstairs to eat to the no reservations policy this place does a great job of bringing Japanese yakitori to NYC. I always sit at the bar, order a random array of chicken parts and have my favorite cocktail, the "nama grapefruit sour" (the best in NYC). The ambiance can be a little noisy and tight, but if you go on the later side, it is really cozy and great for a romantic fun dinner with someone who loves grilled chicken Japanese-style.
The Yakitori and tapas here is amazing.  Thats why its also pricey.  The place is small so usually there's a wait so call ahead of time if you can.
I am comparing to Yakitori joints in Tokyo. Food not bad but nothing to rave about either. Quite cramped. Surprised that it receives such good ratings as one of the best Yakitori in NYC.

Fun authentic Yakitori joint. Try not to show up starving because it can get pricy. I'm a big fan of the various chicken yakitori, the wings in particular are really good. Over all I think Ootoya executes yakitori better but Totto has a wider selection.
I feel like an upscale yakitori compare to other places. Quite busy for dinner. So, I become a lunch time fan. It's my favorite place in Columbus Circle neighborhood for now.

Even with a reservation, we had to wait a good 15 minutes for a seat at the bar. During my meal, walk-ins were standing there, staring at us for a large half of the time we stayed. The skewers and donburi are fresh, hot, perfect. If patience is not your virtue, you might not want to go without a reservation though.

I grew up in New York, I love to eat, I have been to many Asian restaurants, I never ever rated any restaurant I been too. But the experience I had in this place was horrible. First of all the hostess are really stupid or they just act like that. They say it's a 30 min wait we waited for an hour that's fine, but what's not fine is skipping through 2 parties and putting someone in front because she thought that was his name. I told her that wasn't the person and she was just acting dumb until she sow me getting mad and actually asked the customer that she already sat down his name and out of respect she should'vE apologized but like I said she's really dumb or just doesn't care. When we preferred the food it took a while for it to come and also like I said maybe it was just my experience there and for the prices it IS NOT WORTH IT AT ALL. This is New York you can find a lot cheaper places then this garbage place.  I would never recommend anyone to this garbage.

Small place that gets quite crowded. What we ordered: Chicken Wasabi, Chicken Rice Scallion Dish, Harami, Pork loin, Chicken Karage, Chicken Wing. They were out of the limited items.  The food was really really good. We loved every skewer. The ambiance not so much.  Service was ok. A bit overpriced for what you are getting. They charged us 9$ for 3 small cups of diet coke that were filled with ice. I am sure they used less than one can for all 3 cups. Not okay.
This was my first time having yakitori. Amazing food :) and sake was really good! We ate so much. I would go again when I am in the city meeting up with my friends.

We basically ordered everything on the menu several of each. I thought it was pretty good but then again, I don't eat much... if you're looking to consume food to the point where you can't breath this probably isn't the place to go.  Can be overpriced but overall it's an experience.  Probably wouldn't come here again because it just seemed like it was overrated.

NIce authentic intimate feel although not enough seats to avoid a long wait despite  the fact there weren't many patrons.   It is one of those restaurants where you can view the food being made in front of you which is pretty cool.  The food was pretty good but not amazing and the prices were reasonable.  I might come back because I live close by but am certainly not craving the food like certain New York restaurants.
No comment

I am not sure if I will come to this place again. Don't order the noodle, 'coz the taste was just ok. The chicken and pork are good and delicate. It is over-priced in total. The waiter was kind of rude to us, and made me feel uncomfortable.
No comment
Tasty but overpriced. My lime sake cocktail was a bust and grilled rice ball came on a stick but many dishes were delicious. The same people run totto ramen which I think is a better deal.

One of my favorite places in NYC. About double the price of Yakitori Taisho, but it still is only a $25-$30 place if you're careful, and the quality is more than worth it, as a lot of the more exotic skewers that fail at Taisho succeed wonderfully here. Easy to enjoy sitting at the bar and watch the cooks make the skewers.
We were first in line and even with getting a taste of everything, we will never return there. Employees were rude and the food had no flavour. Enough said!
No comment

Not your ordinary Japanese dining experience. Tofu, vegetarian, pork, chicken, lamb-chops all cooked robataya style. Grilled in front of your eyes, absolutely delicious! The atmosphere is not great, but the food is well worth it!

Aside from the mushroom (I think it needed a few more minutes on the low heat side of the grill.  We drank it more than ate it), everything was surprisingly tasty.  I say surprisingly because three decades of eating mediocre Japanese food in the US has made me the angry, bitter little man I am today. We've been here for more than a hundred years people... it took you guys 'til now to bring out the good food?  My taste buds want an accounting... a reckoning... a chicken liver.

Came here as a special dinner with my girlfriend because of the top ratings on yelp and I was not disappointed. The restaurant is on the 2nd floor, walk up the stairs and you will see a row of seats on the counter and a few tables. So do come early or be prepared to wait because it gets really crowded here. They will take down your cell number and call you once your table is ready. The food is GOOD...my favorite's the chicken cartilage. That is an order that goes out of stock quickly. When I think of grilled meats and chicken parts, this is the restaurant that comes to mind first.

It's not *terrible*, but for the price? Not spectacular. Portions are pretty darn small, and while you can get some beef tongue here, it's not all too flavorful. A great deal of the food tastes a lot better with a bit more salt and a bit of shichimi on there, but some things like the pork belly-wrapped sticks just aren't cooked properly. The pork belly ends up more desiccated than crisped, for example. Generally speaking, there isn't much of a hard sear going on on their ostensibly electric (not gas) grills. Overall, not impressed, wouldn't recommend. Visited on a Tuesday evening, store was mildly busy.

Yakitori Totto recently opened up its doors for lunch, and their lunch menu is fantastic--an emphasis on donburi and Japanese kebabs, with a delicate miso soup, salad with crack dressing (seriously, I have never tasted salad dressing so good), and some palate-cleansing barley tea, all for $10. The restaurant was strangely empty during lunch, but I can't imagine it'll stay that way for long.
No comment

My favorite piece of chicken is the butt.  So delicious, a must try. Makes the next juiciest chicken you've ever had anywhere else look dry. I've never dropped 50 dollars on CHICKEN and I didn't even regret it.

So, I read the reviews- some raves others not so much. But we love Japanese food and wanted to try a new place for a special dinner. We made reservations, and were told on two separate occasions that if we were 15 minutes late, they would be cancelled. I get it, its a busy, popular spot. No problem, we were all on time and they happily sat us quickly and graciously.  Sadly, it went downhill from there. The not inexpensive bottle of cold sake we ordered was served lukewarm, ruining the delicate flavor and our server, in a blatant attempt to get us to finish and order another bottle, constantly refilled our glasses so it never actually had a chance to cool down in the ice bucket. They had poured all the sake before most of the appetizers even arrived. We declined a second bottle because the first was such a disappointment. Dinner for 4, with appetizers and multiple yakitori mains, was a rushed and throughly unpleasant affair. Overall, the food was ok- a couple of their house specialties were actually quite good. Our server who initially only gave clean replacement plates to the men at the table, forcing the lone woman to ask for a clean plate, was constantly grabbing plates off the table before we had quite finished, in an attempt to rush us out the door. We were not offered or served tea at the end of the meal, and no mention of whether we wanted dessert, as we had clearly reached our allotted one hour limit for a meal. Is it authentic food? Yes. If you are in a rush and don't have time to linger over or even thoroughly chew your food, this could work out for you. If you need to run to a show in the theater district, for example, I can almost assuredly say you can have a fast meal here. As for me, there are so many other yakitori places to eat in the city, I don't need to come back to this one.
No comment

This place is simply amazing! It's kind of small and can be little loud at times but that is what  yakitori spot is suppose to be. After eating bunch of different skewers, i like to finish with tori zousui. Negi tori don is great, too!
pricey for the ok food, sorry will not return to this place. we try a few grilling meat, fry chicken, rice dish and desert.
No comment
have the dessert tofu! it was fabulous! i thought the beef yakitori was better than chicken!
Tasty grilled bits and fun atmosphere mixed with cold Japanese beer makes for a fantastic late night spot.
No comment

i love thier pork skewers, they have wonderful service and it is always authentic. It's good to drink iced green tea especially when everything you eat will be grilled. They only take reservations over 5 people I believe.
One of the best yakitori places I've tried- taking into account all the yakitori places I've been to in Japan.  Will be returning with friends again!

It is the yakitori place! THE! I went here on one of my last night in NY and everything was worth that long dark walk through the alley away from the lights of time square. The wait was long, but worth it. The atomsphere in the restaurant is amazing... it made the food more enjoyable. Everything was good... I wasn't disappointed at all. I would go back to NY for this place!

Exotic yakitori that feels more upscale than your typical izakaya yakitori serving joint.  The thing that makes this place stand out over other yakitori places is the variety of meats and the quality of the meats.  This place tends to focus more on yakitori as opposed to other yakitori place like yakitori taisho and hagi that serve a wide variety of foods from okonomyaki, age dashi tofu, etc.  The tip for minimal wait is to make a reservation and show up early.  I kind of wished they had a more extensive sake collection, but the vast array of meats for yakitori made it all worth it.  Definately a place i would return to try out their more exotic offerings.

This is a pretty good Japanese skewer place but I fail to see what is so heartstoppingly fantastic about it. After reading the reviews it was quite underwhelming. I tasted 7-8 different dishes from the interesting menu but none of the food knocked my socks off - the bacon-wrapped asparagus was good, the scallop skewer was dry and had little flavor, the Amakara Age was nice and fatty but needed salt, the desserts are very unremarkable. If it's only the yakitori you're after then fine, but there are more fulfilling Japanese restaurants in New York City.
No comment
No comment

Everything was good.  It's a fun restaurant to try because there is a lot of option if you're willing to be a little adventurous and it's very easy to share the food with friends.  The only dish that wasn't my favorite was the pork because it was a bit chewy.  The service was also very good.
No comment

After spending some time in Japan, I was just desperate to find somwhere stateside for authentic and good okonomiyaki (Hiroshima style). This was my first try and I think I will look no further. I live in Reno, so this means a 3 1/2 hour drive for real Japanese food. I'm happy to do it for this restaurant. Sooo gooood. Brought back a flood of memories. Give it a try, no matter what it will taste so much better that you expect!

Superbly executed dinner. I got there 30 minutes before opening, and stood there, no reservation. It worked out, and I was seated immediately with a friend, even though there were many reservations. This is the same amount of attention to detail you get in Japan. If I could afford it, I'd eat here every day.

Came here for lunch and got the pork skewers and rice with an egg. Sadly I think the egg watered down the flavors of the sauce and the pork. Or maybe I was just sad that it didn't taste like the pork donburi at Daikokuya in LA. It's unclear. Might come back for another quick lunch if I'm in the area, sans egg and with extra sauce.

Izakayas are the thing when in NY.  Yakitori Tomo is a decent place, but what makes this place better than average is the quick turn around and friendly service.  Stick with yakitori.  The udon and other dishes while availabe are not their specialty.  If you want to eat noodles, go to a Ramen house.  People too often make the mistake of just ordering anything just because it's on the menu.

We went here tonight for dinner.  Arrived around 11 and was seated promptly.  We tried the chicken meatball dumplings, fried chicken appetizer, chicken breast skewers, and premium beef and was surprised of the basic no frills taste (although the premium beef was quite tasty and for no sauce meat everything was pretty good).  We asked out waiter if they had any sauces and was told quite rudely "No".  Then our spicy Tokusen Oyako Don arrived , and to our surprise was quite good.  There was a very tasty spicy sauce.  We then asked our waiter who barley spoke any English if we could have some of the spicy sauce on the side and was told "No" again.  This time I was looking at the sauce, tasting the sauce I was seeking the whole time and when I was told no I couldn't believe it. I had to get quite rude and undergo multiple rounds of requests in order to have them finally give us the sauce, accompanied by  an extra $2 charge (which I didn't mind), By that time I had to literally argue and express my discontent, asking for the manager, raising my voice, frowning, dead stares at the waiter that this restaurant experience had actually changed my mood.  We were able to laugh about it later but I now hate every single person in this restaurant and I would do pretty much anything to make them understand how unsatisfactory of service they are providing.  I hate you Yakitori Totto, I hate you very very much.

I walked up a dingy, moldy, and smelly staircase to what l had hoped to be a beautiful restaurant. The inside of the restaurant itself is cramped, loud, stuffy, and busy. I asked to be seated (I was on my own for some dinner after work), and was told the wait would be 30-40 minutes. I decided to wait, and asked if it would be possible to charge my phone as I waited. I was told "Sorry, we don't charge phones here." What? Sorry, but I've never had that response EVER while living and dining in New York City. I decided to walk out and try a different restaurant. I won't support an establishment that doesn't try to serve their customers to the best of their ability - it comes off as though this restaurant only cares about what they can make off of their patrons.
No comment
No comment
No comment
This place is quite pricey indeed, but I'm a fan :) Yummy yakitoris :) and their homemade mochi ice cream with peanut powder....orgasmic ;)

So yummy!  My friend and I tried a bunch of different stuff but what stood out were the chicken hearts, chicken meatball, shishito peppers, and dessert!  I highly recommend this place.  Have tried Oh Taisho! and Aburiye Kinnosuke and this is the best.  Show up early though or else you'll be waiting for a while...

If you're used to eating souvlaki or whatever chicken on a stick from that dusty questionable cart on the 45th or 46th or whatever number street you suddenly got hungry at then I'm not sure you're ready for Totto.  This place has really good quality food and although portions are small, its not about the size but the flavor and quality.  I would suggest coming with just one other person and sharing a bunch of different skewers.  And definitely try to make reservations because the wait can be pretty long.  I thought because of the grill being open, that I would reek of japanese bbq but they have pretty good ventilation but not so.

Every time I go to Japan, I have to have some yakitori.  I was quite happy when Totto opened a few years ago.  I went with my mother and cousin and it didn't disappoint.  I love the nankotsu (cartilage) which many people don't like.  It's an acquired taste, but it is great with beer or a chu-hai.  My favorite part of the chicken is the skin. Yes I know it's bad for you, but that's why it's so good. Their homemade tofu is great as well. I would stay away from the dessert as they are mediocre.
Very interesting food and good service at lunchtime.  Prices are great at lunch too.  Small dining room though (seats maybe only 15-20 ppl).

Wonderful restaurant. You can get an idea on what's good here from the other reviews. My only criticism of this place is how cramp and small it is. Being on the 2nd floor, you'd think that they would have more space to work with. But it's still pretty dang small. Regardless, the food more than makes up for its lack of space.

Let me start, by saying, I like chicken... A lot... Almost as much as I like pork... They have both here... And the good parts... The Ass, the Skin, the Hearts, the Neck meats... This is one place, that I don't care how long I have to wait to get in, I will wait... Usually finding myself disappointed to see that much of the "limited" menu is gone, but I make up for it with the sheer volume of chicken I feed my face with.
No comment
No comment

Went to this place in September 2010 but never got around to reviewing it.  This was the first Japanese place my brother and I went to when I first moved into the city.  We went on a Saturday night, the place was tiny (have to go up a narrow stairway to get to it) and it was really crowded. My brother and I sat at the only places at the bar, the service was fast but impersonal.  We had a bunch of different yakitoris and some stuff off the menu.  Everything tasted great to us, so I would recommend that you try the place out for yourself. :)

Always good and always booked, so get your reservations early! This place is very small, but it's a gem! Everything is cooked on a skewer and it's all about chicken. So, order a lot of different items to see what you like, then order more of your favs. Prices are very reasonable.

This place was fantastic. The wait was long, but perhaps that made the meal better because by the time we sat down we were starving.  They did serve us beer while we waited to be seated.   The chicken skin was ridiculous and the chicken with scallion was good too. The asparagus with bacon had good flavor and the asparagus was perfectly cooked, but the bacon was a little on the raw side and I prefer mine very crispy.  Next time I will order the asparagus without the bacon. That said, I can't wait to go back.

The space is very unassuming (small, stuffy cramped and up a vaguely decrepit staircase).  That being said, the yakitori are good.  There is an interesting selection of ingredients and they are well cooked.  Also some unusual drink selections.
Food and drinks and dessert were delicious - great for groups!

Neat and clean Yakitori place...if you like other Yakitori places but don't like the chaotic dining environment, then Yakitori Totto is the place for you. Menu recommendation: all kinds of steak in sauce, negi pork, wonton cheese, and mochi ice cream. I personally think the chicken skewers are dry...the seaweed salad and steamed vege are very good as well, if you want something else than meat (#^.^#)

Great restaurant and amazing food!! Be ready to pay a lot of money $3-5 per skewer but very nice variety and delicious.  I especially liked the Tofo, chicken Liver short ribs and chicken breast.  My friends hand tongue skin heart and all that fun stuff.  Veggies and eggplant were great top.
No comment

We had a quick lunch here - the totto don and the karubi don - and both were delish. The chicken meatball is AMAZING, and if I visit again I will get exclusively that since the other two chicken skewers were a little dry for my taste. Add a soft cooked egg and you have a protein packed lunch to keep you going through a long NYC day!

I'm not sure what I can add to the other reviews, but this place is absolutely amazing. It's rather small, but it still manages to avoid seeming cramped. My coworker and I sat in front of the grill, and it made the tasty food that much more fun to eat. I don't even know what I would recommend, since every dish we ordered was out-of-this-world! The sake collection is great and the service is top notch. In a city of great restaurants, this one is a winner!
No comment
Expensive, but it's to be expected. This is a get what you pay for kind of place. Real traditional and authentic. I would definitely go back for a good meal and great drinks.
Hard to get into, but when you do you won't regret it. Delicious. The chicken meatball with sauce is the winner every time. Sake was fantastic.

Wasn't too thrilled with the service here after watching Wicked on a Thursday night. However, I did enjoy the tofu and loved how they serve fried chicken skin! Tight space... wouldn't go out of my way to return.
No comment
Secret to happiness: Chicken knees, tail and skin.  Grilled rice ball with yakitori sauce.  And iced banana dessert.  Do not get your cholesterol checked the next morning.

The food is good, but the service always leaves something to be desired. There is nothing specifically wrong, but whenever I talk to the waiting staff they act like they're doing me a favor. This place went from being one of my favorites in the city to a place I'd never go back for that reason and the long waits.

Definitely one of my favorite places in midtown...which aren't many. Make sure you call for reservations before 7p if you don't want to wait which is guaranteed if you simply walk in. The Pork with Scallions is to die for. And the Chicken Soup is simply lovely.

Yakitori Totto, I hate you.  I hate you because you are too damn tasty and now I feel like a stalker ex-boyfriend that won't leave you alone.  Your gizzards were nice and chewy, wings flavorful and your skin melted in my mouth.  Sapporo draft beer complemented well with the skewers and the kamameshi was pungent with chicken aroma and excellent.  The ambiance and decor was great and made me feel like I was at a high end yakitori place in Japan.  But our wonderful night together eventually ended and I had to go back to California.    I won't forget what we had together and I will be back!
No comment
No comment
No comment

This place is so good.  There is a line outside of this restaurant before it open.  I try almost everything on the menu, and trust me, almost everything is good.  I would love to open a restaurant like this.  There are no Yakitori restaurant in Houston, TX, so sad!!! people are missing out.  There are some restaurant that serve robata here in Houston, but only offer like 3 to 5 different yakitori and they don't really do it right.  Cant wait to come back to New York just for this
Yakitori like in Tokyo!!!  Keep in mind you need a reservation (wait times can be *quite* long without one)... but it's worth it.
Really good. Reasonable price. A little tight.
No comment
No comment

Food is good but seems to be disappointingly over-hyped. My friend and I tried a variety of the yakitoris (I like offal) mostly chicken, a little beef and vegetable. Everything was cooked well, but anything with a sauce on it - namely the eggplant dishes - were much too salty for my tastes. For dessert we ordered sesame ice cream, but they wouldn't let her get two different flavors for some reason. For my money I rather go to Takashi for some fancy grilling.
No comment

Chicken Oyster is the best piece of chicken you will every taste in this town!  Their Ocha Zuke is also simply wonderful.  If only they'd take reservation and NOT have to make you wait in line for at least 45mins...  Will definitely go again =)

Don't get the fried chicken here, it's not that good, I've definitely had better. You must try the chicken with rice clay pot dish. I'm not sure what they infuse into the rice, but it's just the right amount of flavor. This place gets 3 stars because you're forced to spend a minimum of $20 and because the waitress was rude and unresponsive. I'd probably come back again for the chicken with rice clay pot dish. As indicated on the menu, it takes 35 minutes to prep!
No comment

Came here last night with a few friends and I wasn't impressed with the service or the food here. The yakitori was $3 a skewer which is standard in NYC and some of them were really delicious (beef tongue and gizzard) but the servers were really disorganized which ruined the whole experience. Our skewers were dumped on the table and the waiters were already walking away when they told us what was what. We were even given 4 chicken skewers we didn't order and when they figured it out, they gave it to the correct table who wanted them replaced. Can't blame them, I wouldn't want chicken skewers that were sitting at the wrong table for 5 minutes. Also we tried the chicken meatballs that were coated in sticky rice and steamed. Those were bland and needed to be doused in soy sauce for any flavor. In the end we paid $40 each for a dinner that barely filled us up.

Hard to find anything on the menu that isn't ridiculously delicious. I'm not going to pretend that I have any expertise in Japanese cuisine whatsoever, so I kind of just read up on Yelp before I came to know what to choose.. and then added a few things that sounded good along the way. Every item they brought out was better than the last. First of all, yes, there is a wait... even during a downpour. But while you're waiting, ask for a drink. It'll make the time go faster! Highlights of the meal included Totto's Kimchee (how I loooove pickled foods!!!), Negi Pon (pork loin with scallion and ponzu), Pork Mustard (clears your sinuses right up!), and Chicken Oyster. I was a little conflicted about the Negi Tori Don at first.. initially, the flavors seemed blander than the other dishes. But once you mix it all up, it easily becomes the highlight of the meal because of the texture of the rice alone. This place is super-authentic, a really cute place for a date, and perfect for a New York night. Can't wait to come back here -- thank goodness it's right around the corner!!

We had a bunch of stuff. The flavors were good but it doesn't make me a chicken fan. Liked the sake lime and the other cold sake we ha a lot. Weird! I likedthe drinks more than the food.  I think I'd appreciate this food In street food scene in japan more.

Somehow spent $70 per person here. Which really seems insane to me. I blame my friend Tommy and his alcohol-ordering. Lots of sake and beer add up, I think. I think the bill would have been 1/4 of the price had we just stuck with food. We did two rounds of yakitori, but by the second I was so full! We basically tried every single thing on the menu, not exaggerating. The stand outs were definitely the pork neck (don't feel weird, just order it, it was GREAT), the chicken skin, heart, gizzard, and tongue.

My friend and I went right when they opened their doors for dinner time and we were seated pretty quickly. We sat at the bar/grill. We enjoyed watching them cook the yakitori. We got a bunch of them -- pork (my favorite), beef and chicken. Their rice dishes are good too.

Very small Yakitori restaurant upstairs.  Crowded. SO go early or late.  Small group 2-6 max.   Stick with Yakitori all the way.  Chicken anything is great.  The scallops were good but a bit small.  The Tofu dishes are great.  The disappointing thing was the deep fried octupus.  That was a definite miss.  Wish there was more sauce choices.  Sevice was excellent.  Would highly recommend.

I prefer to come here for lunch as it gets cramped comes dinner hour. Food here is really good: beef ramen, chicken thigh skewers with rice, scallops, skirt steak, shishito peppers, miso eggplants, duck. Genuine japanese yakitori.
No comment

We ordered a whole bunch of skewers. The wagyu beef and chicken heart were my faves. The chicken thigh, pork belly, shisito stuffed with chicken were all very good. The okra and mushrooms not so much. However, we enjoyed the experience very much.
No comment
No comment

This is one of the best Japanese resturants in NYC.  Def recommend to anyone who like authentic Japanese food.  It is definately genuinely Japanese, the food is really good, and worth the prices they charge.  They do get busy though so you need to plan timing.  Espcecially on Friday.  Not enough accolades for this place.  Everyone go!

I love this REAL yakitori place. But little pricey. it's just yakitori (that's why rate 4)... anyway I love their takikomi gohan. It's just cooked rice but cook in front of you with small pot and taste very nice.

Ok this place rocks. It's tiny, upstairs and doesn't open until 5:30 for dinner, but it's worth the wait. The little skewers give you the opportunity to try many different types of items for dinner. I especially enjoyed the scallops, flank steak, pork with ponzu and scallions, and the special meatballs in tiny little peppers. Be sure to sit a the bar so that you can watch the cooks grill up all of the little skewers. A thoroughly enjoyable experience! If I were given the choice between Yakitori Totto and Saki Bar Hagi, my brain would probably explode because both are excellent.
I think Yakitori Totto is overrated and overpriced...  I'd much prefer and recommend Tori Shin instead

My all time favorite Yakitori place in town. I like its simple wabi-sabi deco aesthetics. This translates into their food preparation. The chicken here is so tasty however they make it. The salad with the tiny fish and semi-cooked egg is amazing! Good sake selection. But it's always crowded, so you have to get there early and be prepared to wait a bit. It's worth it!
Other than the fact that you have to wait about an hour to eat here, food is fabulous!  Lots of different things to try here.

I'm from los angeles came here on vacation and I must say this place is DELICIOUS!! We waited almost an hour an a half..super packed an also tiny but it was definately worth the wait!!& we got the little exclusive room so that was a plus!! Ps! The vanilla mochi is to die for!

Two friends and I walked over here on a Tuesday night around 7 PM. It was about an hour wait, so we walked over to the bar across the street while waiting for them to call us. Around an hour later, we got a phone call and were seated. We had lots of different yakitori, and everything was delicious. The kimchee was also very good. Well worth the wait!

Tiny and delicious grilled bites. I guess $3+ a skewer is fair since they're tasty, but I do wish that there was a little more food on each one. Very good service and only waited 50 minutes, for a party of 6, after arriving at 7:45 on a Thursday.
Pricey, but they spend time crafting the right juxtaposition of flavors to create balanced plates. Must try the fresh made tofu adding your own seasoning to taste.

So after checking in with the hostess, I was very close to leaving.  Not only was the wait 45 minutes, the hostess was rather rude!!  After deciding to just wait it out, we got our table in 30 minutes.  I was super happy we did after we received our meal for EVERYTHING was cooked to perfection and the quality of the food was high.  It was so good that I didn't care about the bad impression that I first got!  Very excited to go back on my next trip to NYC.
No comment

Wow!  Just had a delicious meal at Yakitori. Every chicken and beef related item was so tasty, fresh and unique. We ordered the chicken breast skewer, short ribs, flank steak skewers, chicken soup, croquettes, and udon. My single fav was the soup, it really hit the spot but as i said before every item we ordered was fantastic. Dont forget to order sake and some dessert too! You gotta try the black sesame ice cream!!

Very friendly service, allowed me to have a table right away when my party was all present. Mind you I waited in the store for 1hr before the rest of my party showed up, there were only two of us.  The music is very nice and upbeat making this place an awesome hang out spot, just the space is very limited so be aware that there will be lots of bumping into your chair. The food is savory-ish but not extremely awesome. The tsukune sauce was flavorful but the kawa (skin) was alright, just a crunch not much flavor. The hotate (scallop) had a good texture but the flavor had a bit of the seafood smell. If you like very chewy gyutan then this is the place to go, it's not chewy like rubber band but it wasn't a there to four chew swallow, more of a seven to eight. But in all the food was decent anne the place us nice, just too crowded and jammed.
L-o-v-e. My favorite. So much fun. You must sit at the bar -- and make sure to order a couple of skewers of pork neck.
No comment

OK its disgusting the amount of times I have over ate here. I love this place for Yakitori, everything is so well made. I don't think its possible to have a bad meal here. The only problem is the place is small and sometimes the wait can be terrible but most of the times I've been there it was fine

Shared a few skewers and all except maybe one were great. It's expected you won't like something when you're trying all these weird parts you're not used to eating, but I liked most. Even some that I thought I wouldn't, like heart (or maybe it was liver). You can get regular cuts and I mostly did, but where's the fun in just eating what you're used to. I recommend the stuffed rice balls.

Decent food, but the service is so bad I want to vomit.  The hostess will rush you out.  Why??? I complain in front of them and they say "thank you!" ... Wtf... Asians just don't know service.  They only care about turning tables.  (I can say this bc I'm Asian).  Don't waste your time here.  I eat yakitori all the time and sake bar hagi is leaps and bounds better.  This place will go downhill fast with their unbelievable stupor.  Yay to dumb, useless little Japanese hostess'.  I could hire better, more polite monkeys as opposed to these mistakes of life.  I urge these Neanderthals to quit and suck their thumbs in the corner of a small box in the fetal position.  That's all they're good for.

I was excited about this because I have been craving yakitori and haven't tried one in NYC yet. When I saw this was featured with Anthony Bourdain, what can go wrong right? Wrong. I didn't have a reservation but I was seated straight away since it was early (6pm). The first thing I noticed is that they ask for $20 min spend per head. I thought, fine. I ordered a couple of skewers, Maguro sashimi, takoyaki and beer and ice cream between 2 and the bill is already over $100. you'd think for the price there should be good quality control and service right? Wrong. First came the Takoyaki. They were still cold from the fridge. Then came the skewers- the chicken was undercooked, the rest was fine even though I was surprised how quickly they came out. Before I even finished my skewers, the waiter kept pushing us to order dessert or get the bill. This was 6:30pm. Barely much time to chow down food and enjoy my company. I ordered ice cream, and then they brought me the bill with it to ask us to hurry up and leave! Incredible. I bided my time to EAT the ice cream while the server kept checking to see if we've paid. Obviously NOT! I didn't even ask for the bill. When I paid and just let myself out, it was 7pm $50 per head for poorly cooked food only to shoo you out within an hour? Seriously. Even Mcdonalds would treat you better. If they're worried about reservations then they shouldve told me. I wouldve gone elsewhere. But no. They want my money but I certainly won't be going back.
its alright, the food is expensive compared to how mediocre it tastes

Very hidden and small, sometimes you have to wait an hour to get a table but still enjoy going there for dinner. There is nothing fancy about this place but food is really amazing. The meat is so tasty.
No comment
If you want a table around 7 pm, you will need to make a reservation a day ahead, at least, or wait about 45 min to an hour. They have large and good choices, and each item we ordered were good.
No comment
No comment
No comment

I've returned to Totto 2x times since my first review and it has gotten better in terms of service and taste. I also been there for dinner and had sake. Although they don't serve whole bottles of sake but a regular cup is pretty big. I am a huge fan. It's now 5 stars!

This place was as amazing as I hoped it would be. We had some great food, including some of the best dumplings I've had for a really long time. The service was quick and friendly and we got seated right away - I'm going back for sure!

Love the yakitori!!!! I tried a lot of them and they were all so very tasty, well seasoned . I was skeptical about the the knee bone and the neck bone and I said to myself " why do u want to pay 4 bucks for bones?" . But the bone was very crunchy and well seasoned, u wouldn't think u were eating bones. All the fried items had a very thin,not heavy batter. The taste was just awesome. Definitely try their shochu cocktail( citrus), and the fresh fruit. I loved it.

Sake and grilled stuff on sticks.  Fresh, hot, made with great care.  Excellent kim chee.   Tiny space, waits can be long.  Seems favored by Japanese folks away from home.   Service is quick and efficient - they need to turnover seats, so stagger your order so you can slow down the pace.  All them little sticks of deliciousness can add up to a big check so be careful.

I've learned my lesson finally, never go back to a restaurant you went to over 10 years ago in NYC. It happened with Basta Pasta, now Yakitori Totto. They specialize in chicken dishes and they were the worst dishes. I think dessert was the best. Enough said.

Don't visit here if you believe that grilled chicken sticks should be reasonably priced.  Totto is paying Midtown real estate prices while trying to deliver back alley yakitori style cuisine.  Having said that, go early and sample the rarities - they sell out quickly.  The salads and rice-based dishes are delicious and generous.  The yakitori is done visibly (yet not smokily) and is delicious.

Found the restaurant thru Yelp; excellent choice. Loved the atmosphere, the service, and the quality. The idea of small selectable items is great and traditional Japanese. You have the opportunity to select what you like and to try new adventures......great place and I would recommend. Small so call ahead or get there early.
Have been here many times and it is the highlight of my trips east. The food is as good if not better to the best Yakitori places I go to in Osaka. The Saki and Shochu selection are outstanding.
No comment

The food here is very good, the ingredients are fresh, and the drinks selection is fine.  A bit overpriced ($3-6 per skewer for items that would be $1.50-4 in the E. Village) but there are a few unique options (Kobe beef skewers anyone?) and the appetizers are very good (always love the fried chicken).
No comment

Went here based on Yelp's reviews.  There was a bit of a wait (we had no reservation) but only 10 minutes and we ate at the bar.  Fantastic Yakitori.  My favorites were the chicken meatball one and the skirt steak.  The mushrooms and asparagus with bacon were also really good, everything was fantastic though, a great meal.

So far the most authentic Japanese robata I have in NYC. Always crowded and long line up so be prepared to practice your patience. Highly recommend to make reservation ahead! Portion is ok for a higher med scale of sakeya. Must try the chicken skin (kawa), shiokara (preserved squid) and chicken/ pork skewers. Good to have 2-3 friends having sake and light eat together.
tried this early this year with my colleagues after work. very busy place but great services. All foods are just awesome!
Best Yakitori we ever had! One of the bet desserts we ever had!! This is a must visit in NYC. We come here every time ;)
Great food, loved the bacon mushroom wraps, fried chicken and the best seaweed salad ever.
No comment
No comment
No comment
They use simple ingredients to create surprisingly delicious dishes from the appetizers to the desserts. Very satisfying.
No comment

They've got great yakitori! Service is good, food is perfect! A chef grilling yakitori seemed like he was having a blast! That made us happy too! But Soba totto's yakitori is a little bit better with a larger portion.
ummm wow. this was an experience right out of an Anthony Bourdaine special.  I just ... can't even! I have no words to describe how awesome this was- just go,  have an adventure and visit this space!
No comment
No comment
No comment
Best yakitori by far I've had in NYC, and right up there with the best I ever ate in Japan.  Can't wait to go back.

Great yakitori. The place is fairly small and really hard to get a seat during prime dining hours.  Recommend coming right when they open so you can get a good seat and some of their more popular pieces.  I was seated 5 minutes after opening and informed that the other table had ordered all the chicken oysters.  You can taste their attention to detail in the skewers.  Each is perfectly seasoned and cooked.  Not cheap per se but on average with what you'd pay at a good yakitori place in Tokyo
No comment
No comment

Recommended by a good friend who just moved West. The food is good. The service is good. Reservation part was a bit tricky. Called several times with answering machines, got there, they asked for reservation, when we (obviously) didn't have one, the wait was an hour...
Food is delicious, but expensive and small portions, would recommend the skirt steak skewer, tongue, baby octopus, chicken hearts, ramen soups
Very decent food however not super impressive with the price. The two of us spent $150 and were barely full walking out.

30 minute wait after climbing the steep stairs to this second story eatery. Worth the wait, half the diners were Japanese, the other half a mix of local and visitors. Ordered an assortment of yakitori, the skirt steak was the best the rest did not disappoint. Highly recommend!

The chicken tsukune was surprisingly delicious, very delicate, juicy and flavorful. The skirt steak skewers were cooked just right, very tender and juicy. The annin tofu dessert is good if you like desserts that are delicate and refreshing, a good contrast to end a meal focused on heavy grilled skewers. The only issue was the food came really slowly.
Nice place. Very crowded. Make a reservation. Meat is cooked nicely. Simple way of preparing food. Expensive for quality and quantity.
No comment
No comment

I used to love this place, but last time I went (about 2 years ago) I got campylobacter (food poisoning from eating undercooked poultry) which made me very sick within an hour of finishing my dinner.  It makes me sad because the food tasted good, but I'm not risking my health for that again.

The first bite I took at Yakitori Totto was not of anything Japanese in particular. It was just a salad. I was amazed at how the tomato tasted like a tomato should; it was extremely fresh and tasty. The dishes that followed did not fail to impress me either. We ordered a few small Yakitori dishes and shared between us. They were all small dishes that tasted heavenly. The desert was great too. The atmosphere is somewhat mysterious and dark, which I like. It's in midtown; so a great place to go after a Theatre show, it's worth the hike!
No comment
No comment
No comment
Great service, fantastic yakitori, great value - the website says the best yakitori in NYC and man is it true!
No comment
No comment
No comment
Long ass wait but worth it. Go for short ribs, skirt steak, mustard pork and duck. You won't be disappointed.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Amazing!! This was my first yakitori experience and it was great. Get a little bit of everything. The first rice dish on menu was excellent! Also loved the chicken with wasabi and the asparagus wrapped bacon. Every single dish we ordered was great. Do yourself a favor and eat here. Its not cheap by any means.

What I love most about this place is the food. What I appreciate most about it is the consistency. I've been here a dozen times and never have I left feeling less than fully satisfied. With or without alcohol, any day of the week, any time of the year. Of course, the meal's always best if I can get there at 5:30 and have my go at the chicken oysters, knee bones, neck, and everything else that sells out by 6:30. Even better if I can get there at 6:30 and eat all of the aforementioned goodies without having to wait an hour before being sat. It's all good though. The wait seasons the tummy. And sold out specials just means ordering more of the other goodies--gizzard, liver, skin, thigh, shitake... even the tofu (both deep fried and fresh), marinated octopus, salmon roe, silverfish, eggplant & mochi... all make me giddy with pleasure! Ok, the only thing they can't do is kimchi. I'm not quite sure what it's doing on the menu but it's all good--I just ignore that it's there ;-p

I've been wanting to try Totto Ramen for a while and when my friend suggested Yakitori Totto today for lunch since there was no wait and it's a sister restaurant, I got excited. We split the Totto Ramen and the Totto Don lunch specials, which were averagely priced for the city ($9 & $10.50). The miso soup was standard but the complimentary salad was really good! I am normally not a salad eater but the dressing was delicious. I felt bad because I offered my salad to my friend but ended up eating it hah. On to the main dishes - that ramen is the best ramen I have had so far, which includes Ippudo's. I love the spicy sesame oil in the broth, which was soo good even though I normally don't like spicy food. I even drank the broth, which I normally don't do. The noodles were cooked perfectly. The rice was ok, a bit too moist for my taste but the chicken meatball skewer was good - comparable to the ones from St. Mark's. The nigima and wing skewers were a bit bland and not memorable but were cooked and presented nicely.  I would come back here for lunch if I am around the area because the food is great, the space is nice, and there is no wait for lunch. It's too bad this is so far from my office or I'd definitely come here more often.

So I don't remember exactly what it is we ordered at this place except that we loved it. The ambience, the food - I remember it was all so good. My fiance and I were here 4 or 5 years ago and walked here after watching a broadway show. It is on the second floor of a building. One of my fiance's clients had lived in NYC and recommended this place as a must go. The wait was so long and I remember thinking, wow! This place is filled with all Japanese people speaking Japanese. Must be legit. It was TOTALLY legit. Every time I go back to NYC I think, I must hit up this place again. I never get to make it back here because there are so many restaurants I want to try but haven't tried. Maybe next week when we're in NYC I will come here again and see if there is a need to update my rating (doubtful!). Seeing pictures of the yaki onigiri alone is making me drool.

A very unique experience with very high quality food. The very tight space makes it feel like you are in Tokyo. Has a nice dim ambience. The food is very tasty and well prepared. It's nice that each skewer is so cheap, so you can try a great variety of options!
No comment

This was one of the better yakitori places I've been to~ An important thing to note is that this restaurant requires that each patron spends a min of $20... my friend and I was not aware of this and was sort of forced to order more. Staff could definitely be more friendly but at least they're attentive. We esp enjoyed the pork belly with lemon something something. We also shared one of the chicken dons - delish!

I absolutely loved the chicken thigh and the pork skewers.  Gizzards and chicken thigh "oysters" weren't as tasty as I thought they'd be, but provided a nice contrast to everything else.  I also enjoyed the donburi and chicken karaage.  The place is rather small, but we were seated quickly.

I've been coming here for almost 5 years now and i'm never disappointed.  Best yakitori in the USA.  Honestly every dish is amazingly good.  Only reason is not a 5 star is because one of their signature skewer was the specialty chicken meatball but they just took it out of the menu !!! I don't know why !!!  Please bring it back.  Also the specialty skewers run out really fast, so if you are not there early, most likely it will be sold out.

We started with the fermented salmon, monkfish liver, croquettes and spicy cucumbers. Sadly, these were average. Moving onto the Yakitori, we adventured onto hearts, tails(chicken butt), skins, tongues and a few vegetables for good measure. Definitely tasty! My wife who had not eaten innards before took them on without any repulsion, just delight; that says something about how good they taste. We felt the undisputed champs of the menu were definitely the meatballs. We repeated the process of sake and meatballs that we left no room for dessert.

this place is yummy.  we ordered the homemade tofu, avocado and tuna, scallops and miso eggplant skewers, egg roe over rice.  my fave was the homemade tofu, which came w/ a bunch of toppings for you to do yourself.  if you sit at the bar, make sure to wear something washable, b/c you will smell when you come out!!

My first time at a place like this...and I can't see any other yakitori being any better than this..I mean, this was absolutely phenomenal..such a refreshingly different and unique experience for me. I am starting to realize that japanese cuisine in its variou forms might just offer more for me than French cuisine does. I mean this meal was a fraction of the price of going to Michelin-starred restaurant and I left happier and learned more about food than when i go to any of those places. Obviously, I had every part of the chicken ..all presented on skewers and all perfectly seasoned and cooked...I mean PERFECTLY...I've never had such delicious chicken. Really...who gets f'n excited over chicken? I F'n do now. Chicken skin, neck, thigh, soft-bone, liver, meatballs, ass, heart..everything awesome...especially the chicken ass..what can I say, I am an ass man. Awesome apps too...deep fried octopus..best way I ever had octopus, terrific kim chee and tuna sashimi. Mostly Asian clientele so you know the place i great. Wow, writig this review and reflecting on my meal is making me want some ass...chicken ass that is

came here as a walk-in and the wait was approx 1 hr but well worth it.  they take your number and call you 5-10 min prior to your seat availability.  the food here is so tasty.  My favorite skewer was the kobe beef tongue.  It was so chewy and had just enough salt to make it my favorite skewer.  The chicken thigh was good.  I ordered the croquettes which I wasn't a huge fan of.  Fearing I wouldn't have enough food, I ordered a rice bowl with chicken and a poached egg.  Though full, I still ate it and it was so good.  Just enough soy sauce and the egg was cooked perfectly.  I would come back here for food quality alone.  Next time I'll make reservations in advance :p
Very good japanese restaurant. Food is not expensive. The environment is good. One point not so good is that the server is not so friendly...

Absolutely fantastic meal! The rice bowls are delicious and the service was wonderful. The restaurant is geared towards smaller parties, but i went with a party of 4 and the wait was not long whatsoever. I am really impressed with the food coming from San Francisco, home of many great Yakitori places. I would highly recommend to any one looking for good quality, great tasting good. The atmosphere is great and the service was good!

excellent yakitori... a bit pricier than the joints downtown but they have more authentic yakitoris...like brain i think.  definitely worth checking out if you're in the area and don't want to deal with the asian madness of the other two yakitori joints in saint marks.

Food was ok, really nothing special. We had about 7 items. What was most striking was how expensive it was. Our bill for 2 people ( all yakitori) was $93 and we weren't even full. They also charge for tea refill. Beef tongue in particular was very tough
Confirmed. The best yakitori in NY. Much better than the others in terms of meat quality and spices.
Best hatsu in NYC!

Nothing special. Went there with my husband, sat down at a tiny table. Place was packed. According to the reviews, the food is suppose to be amazing, but nothing wow. We tried almost all the BBQs and some starters, but there is nothing to be amazed about. Wont be back.

went there at 6pm with reservation and let me tell you..i haven't been this excited about yakitori since i left the streets of tokyo. they have all the chicken parts like they should. i guess they sound gross but they ALL are delicious..REALLY. i reccomend going there early as possible just so you wont miss out on the limited quantity items like chicken knee cartlige(LOL, told you it sounds gross). they have a good selection of sake, and i'm addicted to the fresh grapefruit sour. the extra good thing about this place is that above the yakitori-grill, there is a HUGE ventilator that is really quiet, so you wont smell like yakitori=wont confuse yourself with a yakitori in your sleep.
No comment
The waitresses took care of us very kindly with attentive service. Every food was very delicious, and especially yakitori was very soft and tasteful!!
No comment
It's somewhat pricy, but I have to admit that the food here taste very good. People waited in line even it's about 10pm. The service is also good.

The Yakitori at Totto is good, no doubt. It won't knock you off your chair, but it's good. Anyone who doesn't love meat on a stick should be considered at least marginally insane (including those crazy hippie vegans). So let's say you go to this place with a solid appetite and want to get your fill of some good ol' dead animal protein. You order a couple of Yakos and they bring out a few of the mini shish kebabs. You eat them, you're still hungry, you order 5 more, you're still hungry, you drink some sake, you order a side dish, then BAM! They stick you with a $30+ bill! If that's not bad enough, your date (who stuffed herself full of $40 worth of Yakos and is starting to look like Rosie O'Donnell) sticks you with her part of the bill too. There goes your booze money for the weekend. Don't get me wrong, they're good. But if you're a big (and not even fat) guy like me who wants the protein and can't get full without blowing $30-40 here AND can't hardly fit in the cramped space, just take $10, head down the street, and go to Island Burgers & Shakes. It's just as good but WAY less money.  The Yakitori is solid, but it's a "Totto" ripoff!

I like this place. I've only been there for dinner and always had to wait for the seat. I always order Totto salad. Dressing and the chicken on top are yummy:) price is around 60-80/person with beers.

The menu is limited and more geared towards adult tastes but both my girls, 11 and 13, found something worthwhile and very tasty.  Keep in mind these are all small plates, but priced accordingly and all prepared with an obvious attention to detail and presentation. The shitake mushrooms (a mere two on a skewer, were especially tasty. The ahi tuna, fantastic, tender and worth a repeat. The seaweed salad was plentiful and complex in flavor and, again, worth repeating. We had two orders of Udon with Chicken, vegetables and mushrooms were reportedly very very good, though they took a lot longer to arrive. Good food is worth waiting for and, honestly, the wait was not too long. It only seemed longer because the edamame and the seaweed salad arrived almost instantly.  Let the line of people waiting to get a table be your reference if nothing else. This place has a slightly lively ambience, full of young hipsters and older folks who know good food. A definite repeat.

My friends suggested this and I'm glad I came here to try it. The food was delicious! I especially enjoyed the tsukune, the hatsu (beef hearts), and the skin. My boyfriend really liked the short rib and the shishito peppers. The one dish we did not like was the fried chicken dish... I've had much better renditions of this in SF so it was really a meh dish. Service was pretty fast and efficient but the one thing that made me give it 3 stars instead of 4 stars (if it was only based on food) was that they had initially told us a 5-15 min wait over the phone... we walked over there in 5 mins and it had ballooned up to 30 mins. I think we ended up waiting a hour. I much rather them overestimate the time than to keep us waiting since we had somewhere to do after dinner. Overall, I would go back since it was one of the best yakitori places I've been to, but I would def. make a reservation next time.

I called to make reservations a week before i wanted to go, the lady on the phone asked me when I wanted to go, what time and my phone number etc. I thought that the reservation was complete, however after she found out I needed a table for 6, she told me it was booked and I can just come in and wait for a table. I wasnt sure why she asked me all these questions to tell me that they were booked. The day that I went, my friends and I waited about 30 minutes which wasnt so bad. While we waited the chefs were screaming something that I didnt really understand. I think they were saying welcome and bye to the guests. We got this private area in the back which was nice. Our waiter seemed a little nervous but he was really nice. He messed up some of our orders. But it was ok, at the end he resolved it. Everything we ate was really good. I really enjoy the beef tongue ( really chewy), meatball, chicken heart ( taste like some liquid squirt out of it when I ate it), and the udon (the noodle is thinly than I am use to). I love how they have three small bowls of salt and favoring so you can add on it for extra taste. I felt the short rib and skirt steak needed some favor, so this was perfect. I felt like everything I ate was really good. I felt I needed to eat a lot to be full, so at the end I ordered some udon. The udon was really good, the soup taste so yummy. Even though the stewers are inexpensive when you order a lot, the bill adds up. For a group of six we spent about $230. Before we left we decided to have some dessert, I had the Affogato, which was vanilla ice cream, mochi (which had no filling in the inside), sweet red bean, tapioca and hot green tea (you had to pour it in yourself). I felt that the dessert was really good, except I wish the mochi had some filling in it, I think that would make it taste better. Everything was really good and they didnt rush us out, which I was surprised because their was a long line outside. As we were walking out the chefs said goodbye to us. The food is really good and the service is good too!

The food is 4 stars but unfortunately the price is high for what you are paying for. I think the food tastes better at St. Marks and it's definitely cheaper. In any case, it's a nice ambiance, food is decent, but I probably won't come here again voluntarily.

Very delicious BBQ on a stick, namely the soft chicken knee and various grilled veggies.  On a typical Tuesday night it was packed to the brim with a very long wait. The portions are really tiny (like 1 single asparagus stick chopped into 4 pieces), and around $3-4 per stick the bill quickly added up. The three of us came out to $150 with tax and tip, yikes and spikes. I would not recommend any of their rice dishes: very mediocre, small, and expensive.  If I wanted rice with veggies and a raw egg I would have gotten that at Ktown for much better taste and deal.
